Contamination OCD OCD fears involve intrusive thoughts about being contaminated due to touching, or being close to, certain objects, people, or situations, such as doorknobs, individuals with varied illnesses, and bathrooms. Approximately, 46% of patients with OCD have contamination fears that are often associated with becoming sick or spreading germs to others (Markarian et al., 2010 ). Contamination fears can also lead to feelings of disgust and beliefs that they may never feel clean. Another common concern is cross-contamination, a phenomenon in which contaminants spread or transfer from the initial contaminated object (e. g., spoon) to additional objects (e. g., bowl, plate). Individuals with contamination OCD OCD engage in excessive cleaning/washing rituals, including washing hands, showering, and sanitizing, which can lead to skin irritation or bleeding. Additionally, avoidance of contaminated triggers is common, as is the use of barriers (e. g., paper towels) when handling contaminated objects. Patients may engage in ritualized washing habits, in which they clean their body or objects for a certain amount of time or number of sets until they feel the contaminated area is clean. Reassurance-seeking (e. g., asking if an area is clean) and accommodation (e. g., mother helping child with OCD clean a contaminated area) are also common. Finally, these symptoms can lead to economic burden, as patients may buy excessive amounts of cleaning material or discard benign objects that are perceived as contaminated.
Also referred to as “harm OCD” or “responsibility OCD,” this domain of OCD is characterized by an inflated sense of personal responsibility for harm to oneself or others. Specific harm/responsibility harm/responsibility obsessions include fears of harming oneself or others due to carelessness (e. g., hitting a pedestrian due to being inattentive, providing incorrect information to someone that leads to negative outcomes), fears of harming oneself or others by acting on an unwanted impulse (e. g., pushing a family member in front of a car, stabbing a pet), or fears of being responsible for an untoward event (e. g., fire, burglary, house flood, divorce, death).
Common compulsions associated with harm/responsibility OCD include checking and reassurance-seeking. These compulsions are typically related to the content of the obsessions. For instance, a patient who fears they have run someone over with their car may return to a particular intersection repeatedly to check that no one there is injured or dead. A patient who fears being responsible for a house fire or house flood may repeatedly check that their stoves are turned off, appliances unplugged, and faucets tightly shut. Reassurance-seeking compulsions include repeatedly calling or texting a significant other to confirm their safety, or asking a family member for reassurance that the patient has not harmed someone. Compulsions do not necessarily have to be directly or logically related to the content of the obsessions, however. For example, a patient may develop a ritual (e. g., mentally reciting a phrase, tapping in a specific manner) that decreases decreases their perceived likelihood of a bad event happening. Also common are avoidance behaviors, such as avoiding handling potentially dangerous objects (e. g., sharp objects, vehicles, machinery), avoiding contact with people or living things that could be harmed, or avoiding talking to or writing to others out of fears of communicating incorrect information.
Symptoms of harm/responsibility OCD OCD can intersect with those of other OCD presentations. For example, a patient who also has contamination OCD may fear that they will harm others by spreading germs or contaminants; a patient with unacceptable thoughts/taboo OCD may fear that they will act on an aggressive impulse to harm a loved one; or a patient with scrupulosity OCD may feel the need to confess a perceived misdeed in painstaking detail to prevent their family members from going to Hell.
Within the unacceptable/taboo subtype, individuals often report distress due to intrusive thoughts or images related to sex/sexuality, scrupulosity (i. e., immoral thoughts), or sexual violence violence . These thoughts are ego-dystonic (i. e., are inconsistent with the individual’s perception of their personality or values), which contribute to feelings of significant distress, stigma, or shame. This differs from ego-syntonic thoughts that feel consistent with the individual’s personality, values, feelings, and self-view. For instance, individuals with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder or eating disorders (i. e., anorexia nervosa) are more likely to experience ego-syntonic thoughts. Awareness of this discrepancy between ego-syntonic and ego-dystonic thoughts is critical when working with individuals with unacceptable/taboo OCD thoughts, who may carry carry stigma or shame due to having received negative feedback from peers or clinicians who mistook their intrusive thoughts for true intention or desire to act on those thoughts. The sections below describe the most common categories of unacceptable/taboo thoughts.
Individuals who experience sexually themed obsessions report fears of having a desire to engage in sex or intimate actions with children, family members, or strangers in the community. These intrusive thoughts or images lead to compulsions, including excessive reassurance-seeking or confessing, engaging in self-reassurance/mental rituals (i. e., justifying, reviewing situations that occurred), neutralizing (i. e., canceling out thoughts), and checking for arousal within their body. One of the most common compulsions for this subtype is avoidance. For instance, an individual may may avoid certain locations where children are frequently present (i. e., parks, swimming pools, schools) or physical touch with family members or friends (i. e., hugging, handshakes). An individual may also avoid having sexual contact with their partner or hugging a family member, which may result in feelings of confusion or tension in interpersonal relationships.
Another aspect of this subtype is the fear of being sexually attracted to someone that is not in line with the person’s beliefs about their sexuality. For example, a male who identifies as heterosexual may experience intrusive sexual thoughts or images about other men, resulting in fears of being gay. In addition, a female who identifies as bisexual may experience intrusive thoughts that they are “lying” to themselves and others, leading to uncertainty about whether they are interested in both women and men, despite acknowledging that they are attracted to both genders.
This obsessive-compulsive dimension dimension consists of fears about committing sacrilege/blasphemy, fears about not going to heaven or an afterlife, fears about not truly being a “believer” or having faith, or fears about sinning because of having sexually intrusive thoughts. These concerns are highly distressing and surpass what is typical for their peers within the same religious denomination. As a result of these intrusive thoughts, compulsions are typically centered around excessive involvement in—or avoidance of—behaviors associated with their religion. Common compulsions include excessively praying, frequently attending church, excessively reading scriptures or spreading the gospel to others, seeking reassurance (e. g., consulting with church leaders about salvation or whether they are moral or a “good person,” asking family members excessive questions, engaging in repeated baptisms), and avoiding satanic content (e. g., sections of the bible mentioning Satan, the numbers “666,” movies/media showcasing the devil). Avoiding religious practices as a result of intrusive thoughts can lead to strong feelings of sadness or loss of connection within one’s desired community.
Violent intrusive thoughts thoughts or obsessions are often related to an unwanted fear of harming another person, such as sexually assaulting a child or adult, experiencing unwanted thoughts of dead corpses, thoughts related to stabbing or shooting someone, or intrusive images/thoughts of wanting to hurt themselves (i. e., gun, knifes, rope, shower curtain). As a result of these intrusive thoughts or images, individuals will often engage in avoidance so that the feared outcome does not occur. For example, they may avoid kitchens due to knives, avoid the home of a friend who has guns, or avoid areas at stores that have household appliances. Furthermore, these obsessions can lead to compulsions of confessing, reassurance-seeking, and mental rituals (e. g., mentally reviewing situations or interactions to ensure they did no harm).
Another feature of OCD OCD is concerns related to symmetry and wanting things to feel “just right.” Although individuals with this type of OCD may endorse magical thinking (e. g., “my dad will die if I do not make my bed perfectly”), which lead to feelings of anxiety, it is more common for them to experience feelings of incompleteness or discomfort that are alleviated by symmetry, ordering, repeating, or counting rituals (Vellozo et al., 2021 ). Examples of these rituals include adjusting clothes hung in the closet to be perfectly spaced apart, touching a desk repeatedly until feelings of distress are reduced, and repeating a phrase or rewriting a sentence until it feels “just right.” Patients with these symptoms may present with attenuated insight, which may explain why they are less likely to seek treatment than individuals with other dimensions of OCD (Elvish et al., 2010 ). They are also more likely to have obsessive-compulsive and related (OC-related) conditions, such as tic disorders and skin picking (Mayerovitch et al., 2003 ).

sect2.para: Hoarding disorder Hoarding disorder is characterized by persistent difficulty with discarding or parting with possessions regardless of their actual value. This difficulty is due to a perceived need to hold on to these items and distress related to discarding them. This causes the individual to accumulate possessions to the point that the resulting clutter renders living spaces no longer usable for their intended purpose. To meet DSM-5-TR criteria for hoarding disorder, this accumulation of possessions must cause clinically significant distress or functional impairment impairment , not be attributable to another medical condition, and not be better explained by another mental disorder. The DSM-5-TR notes that an individual with hoarding disorder may have uncluttered living spaces only withintervention from third parties (e. g., family members, cleaners, authorities). The patient’s level of insight is indicated with one of the following specifiers: with good or fair insight, poor insight, or absent or delusional insight.

If a clinician notes the presence of hoarding behaviors, a thorough assessment of symptoms is necessary to differentiate between hoarding disorder, normative collecting, and potential differential diagnoses. In contrast to hoarding, collecting is a widespread, normative behavior characterized by focused, organized, and pleasurable acquisition of a specific category of items, and is rarely associated with social or occupational impairment. Hoarding behaviors can be the consequence of other psychological psychological or medical conditions, in which case hoarding disorder should not be diagnosed. For example, if a patient hoards items due to fears that something bad will happen if they discard them (e. g., throwing away a gift will place bad luck on the gift giver; throwing away an old memento will cause the patient to lose a part of their identity), but does not hoard items for other reasons, then a diagnosis of OCD is more appropriate. Clinicians are reminded, however, that a patient can concurrently have both hoarding disorder and a comorbid diagnosis independent of one another.

Trichotillomania (TTM; also referred to as hair-pulling disorder) involves recurrent pulling of one’s hair that leads leads to noticeable hair loss, accompanied by repeated, unsuccessful attempts to stop pulling pulling . Common pulling sites include the scalp, eyebrows, and eyelashes, and most individuals report pulling from more than one area. Many individuals with TTM experience a building sense of tension near the hair-pulling site prior to pulling, followed by a decrease in tension after the pulling episode, which becomes reinforcing. TTM is also associated with significant impairment in social, academic, and occupational domains (Woods et al., 2006 ). Additionally, environmental variables, such as sensory stimulation (e. g., touching hair), emotional states (e. g., anxiety, boredom), and thoughts (e. g., “I can’t control my hair pulling”), are linked to pulling episodes. Studies have identified “focused” and “automatic” pulling as the two subtypes of hair pulling (Duke et al., 2009 ). Focused pulling includes purposeful hair pulling that is triggered by an intense urge, thought, or emotion, while automatic pulling involves a lack of awareness of the pulling episode, typically during sedentary activities, such as watching television or driving. Although hair pulling can occur in other disorders, such as OCD OCD and BDD, clinicians can differentiate the diagnoses by examining the reason for pulling. For instance, individuals with TTM pull hair in response to an ego-syntonic urge or desire to pull, while a hair-pulling ritual in those with OCD may occur in response to distressing ego-dystonic thoughts. Further, pulling hair with intent to fix a perceived flaw in appearance that is not noticeable to others is more closely aligned with a diagnosis of BDD than TTM.

Excoriation disorder Excoriation disorder , otherwise known as skin picking disorder or dermatillomania, is the act of repetitive picking at healthy areas of skin that causes injury (i. e., bleeding, scarring, scabbing). To receive a diagnosis of excoriation disorder, an individual must cause injury or skin lesions to otherwise heathy skin by the act of picking. An individual must also experience feelings feelings of distress or impairment in their daily functioning. Skin picking often begins during childhood and early adolescence and continues into adulthood. Common skin-picking areas include the face, arms, and hands. Typically, individuals pick with their fingernails; however, tweezers, pins, or other tools can also be used to remove skin. Skin picking is often provoked by emotional, situational, perceptual, tactile, and environmental triggers. For example, an individual may experience an urge to pick due to a situational trigger, such as driving or watching television. Additionally, individuals may experience an urge to pick due to a tactile trigger, such as sensing imperfections on the skin. Emotional triggers, such as feelings of anxiety, sadness, or anger, can also increase the likelihood of skin picking. Individuals will often describe feelings feelings of adrenaline, decreased pain, and being in a “trancelike state” during a picking episode. However, following the skin-picking episode, they often report feelings of guilt, shame, embarrassment, and loss of control. This may result in urges to pick again, thus creating a cycle of skin picking.

Within excoriation disorder, the two frequent skin-picking subtypes that have emerged include emotional/reward pickers and functional pickers. Emotional/reward skin pickers are defined as individuals who endorse strong and frequent urges to pick, experience negative emotions before picking, engage in automatic picking, and report little control over picking behaviors. Functional pickers demonstrate milder symptoms of skin-picking behaviors, have less intense urges to pick, and report less distress/impairment related to skin picking.
